Award.AbstractNarration:
IEEE Cluster conference series is a premier international event for presenting the research results, problem solutions, and insights on new challenges in high performance computing in general and cluster computing in particular. Cluster 2015 will be held September 8-11, 2015 in Chicago; Cluster 2016 will be held the same month in 2016 in Taipei, Taiwan. IEEE Cluster seeks to increase student participation in the conference and the field. Both Cluster 2015 and Cluster 2016 will run specific student-centric sessions during the conference, mainly scheduled during the lunch breaks and after the end of the regular sessions: Research presentation training; Research experience and career guidance; Industry interaction; and, Lunch sessions with best paper candidates.The proposed funding would support the travel of eligible US students. Travel grants will encourage the research interests and the involvement of students in the field who are not well funded and those who are just beginning their participation in the field or are interested in entering it. A special effort will be made to reach out to women and under-represented minorities.
It is proposed to offer up to 10 NSF-sponsored student travel grants in 2015 and up to 8 in 2016.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the Mentoring Program at the IEEE Cluster conference is to let students attending the IEEE Cluster conference become more confident professionals once graduated, independently from the fact that the students may pursue careers in academia or industry. In other words, this mentoring program aims to nourish the next cluster computing generation and help students find their right ecosystem to improve their skills and contribution toward scientific and technology innovations. Therefore, this program is not a forum to present students’ scientific contributions, as other student programs at other conferences may be, but it is a means for training and understanding how to succeed in the cluster computing community.

The program is built on a series of sessions with mentors that complement the conference technical program. The sessions are not structures as lectures or one-way talks; they are rather shaped on the model of work meetings between a group of students and their advisers. Mentors not only convey information to the students, but also provide personal feedback in a friendly and careful manner. In the mentoring program, the topics of discussion are essentially the many aspects of a professional life in the professional and research world, including communication skills, career planning, and personal life organization.

At the IEEE Cluster conference 2016, the program engaged a total of 14 students: seven from Taiwanese institutions, 5 from USA institutions, one from a French institution, and one from a Spanish institution. The five students from USA instructions received financial support from this grant for their travel expenses. Two additional students from USA institutions who were awarded with the travel support to participate in the student program did not attend the conference: one student had visa problems and a second student did not get the permission from the national laboratory where he was intern. Considered the location of the conference and the fact that local institutions in Taiwan do not have the tradition of engaging students in such programs, both Taufer (PI on this award) and Bougé (Student Program Chair) were pleased with the number of attendees.
